entries.meaning: (archaic, rare) A heavy strike with a weapon, tool, or the hand.

verbs.description: smite (third-person singular simple present smites, present participle smiting, simple past smote or smited or (obsolete) smit, past participle smitten or smote or smited or (obsolete) smit)

entries.meaning: To strike down or kill with godly force.
To put to rout in battle; to overthrow by war.
To afflict; to chasten; to punish.
examples: Let us not mistake the goodness of God, nor imagine that because he smites us, therefore we are forsaken by him.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, now only in passive) To strike with love or infatuation.
examples: Bob was smitten with Laura from the first time he saw her.
I was really smitten by the color combination, and soon repainted the entire house.
Who'd be smitten over a bird?
